title: (x) Serif text face and italic w/ swash caps in 1962 USGA book - Devinne, MT Baskerville {Patricia}
content:
From a book published in ’62... I’m pretty sure the body is Century Expanded, but not 100%. I’ve never seen a swash version of Century for the header (“The Start of the USGA”). Is it a different face altogether? Thanks in advance.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828233058im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/excerpt_4208.jpg)

 [‹ Bold Sans, K leg curved, low A bar](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828233058/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40841 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Classic Cover insurance logo classic script - Commercial Script {Patricia} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828233058/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40866 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Eric Gordon

comments.content: I would have to agree with Century, But I’m sure about the top one!
I wouldn’t be surprised if some metal foundry produced a swash version of Century Italic and it’s never been digitized.

The header looks like Baskerville italic (monotype)

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/baskerville-mt/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828233058/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/baskerville-mt/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/baskerville-mt/")

I think the text font is DeVinne.

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/de-vinne/devinne-text/](http://web.archive.org/web/20080828233058/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/de-vinne/devinne-text/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/de-vinne/devinne-text/")

Excellent. I should’ve picked up the Baskerville header type—that swashy T should have given it away. (Hits head repeatedly on desk.)

I’d never heard of DeVinne, though. Century wasn’t too far off, apparently:  
<cite>This revival of the Bruce Foundry’s No. 11 is typical of the nineteenth century types derived from the work of Didot and Bodoni; the face remains popular with lawyers and government printers. In fact, Theodore Low De Vinne opposed this kind of design as hard to print and read; he had Century designed to replace it.</cite>  
(From the MyFonts description.)

Thanks, Patty!
